doc.title: Sanhua A/H (002050.SZ/2050.HK)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Sanhua AH 002050.SZ2050.HK 2Q25 beat AIDC liquid cooling upside potential with stable positioning in robot actuators rai_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Sanhua delivered a 2Q25 results beat, with revenue/gross profit/EBIT/net income at Rmb8,593mn/2,515mn/1,459mn/1,207mn (+19%/+25%/+50%/+39% yoy), \(+3\% / + 10\% / + 21\% / + 14\%\) vs. GSe. 2Q25 GPM/OPM/NPM came in at 29%/17%/14% (+1pp/+4pp/+1pp yoy), +2pp/+2pp/+1pp vs. GSe. 2Q25 was a strong beat especially on margins. HVAC control components remained the core driver (+25% yoy growth for revenue and +53% yoy growth for net profit in 1H25), supported by commercial HVAC demand and rising contribution from low- AC penetration regions, with management now expecting at least 15% firmwide revenue growth and 20- 30% net profit growth in 2025E (vs. year beginning guidance of 10- 15% yoy for revenue/profit). AIDC liquid cooling was topical during the earnings call as Sanhua has long been supplying relevant components (valves, pumps, heat exchangers, CDUs) with its commercial HVAC exposure and the company newly disclosed the revenue size of Rmb1bn+ in 2024 already which we calculate at c.10% global market share and perceive that Sanhua probably has more exposure to data center room cooling than server cooling which is a beneficial buffer with China EV/HVAC growth moderation ahead. EV thermal management showed resilience despite Tesla's weakness (+9% yoy growth for segment revenue and +22% yoy growth for net profit in 1H25). While for humanoid robot actuators, the company guided stable market leadership and initial volume production to kick in from 3Q25 in Thailand factory despite market concerns on supply chain uncertainty as its customer is working on the robot redesign. GPM/NPM expanded meaningfully on the back of economies of scale, tighter cost control, and a favorable mix shift toward higher- margin commercial HVAC, which appear sustainable factors to drive margin improvement going forward. On the improved profitability outlook and revenue beat from HVAC, we raise up our 2025- 30E EPS forecast by 8- 11% and our new 12- m TP for Sanhua increase to Rmb32.7 and HK\(34.4 (from Rmb30.4/HK\)33.2\).
Revenue booked Rmb10,389mn in 1H25, +25% yoy, implying Rmb5,429mn in 2025, +23% yoy.

Goldman Sachs does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.
- GPM recorded \(28.2\%\) in 1H25, \(+0.6pp\) yoy, implying \(29.5\%\) in 2Q25, \(+1.5pp\) yoy. NPM recorded \(12.4\%\) in 1H25, \(+2.2pp\) yoy, implying NPM of \(13.9\%\) in 2Q25, \(+2.6pp\) yoy.

- Segment details: commercial HVAC revenue \(+30\%\) yoy, net profit \(+50\%\) yoy; microchannel revenue \(+30\%\) yoy, net profit \(+90\%\) yoy; inverters turned profitable, with a net profit of Rmb80mn (vs Rmb30mn loss last year); Avecco still loss-making.

- Management raised 2025E guidance from \(10 - 15\%\) yoy growth for revenue and net profit in 2025E to at least \(15\% +\) yoy for revenue and \(20\% +\) (approaching \(30\%\) yoy) for net profit. Growth drivers include contribution increase in low-AC penetration regions such as Europe, India, and Africa, as well as strong commercial HVAC demand (partially driven by data center demand).

- AIDC liquid cooling was topical during the earnings call: Liquid cooling-related component revenue already \(>Rmb1bn\) in 2024, with further acceleration in 1H25. Revenue recognition is spread across HVAC, Microchannel, inverter segments. The company positions itself as a component supplier, not system integrator. Sanhua's core products (valves, pumps, heat exchangers, CDUs), and the company supplies mostly indirectly, through system integrators, making AI data centers indirect customers. We calculate a \(c.10\%\) global market share and perceive that Sanhua probably has more exposure to data center room cooling than server cooling which is a beneficial buffer with China EV/HVAC growth moderation ahead.
- Revenue booked Rmb5,874mn in 1H25, \(+9\%\) yoy, implying Rmb3,164mn in 2Q25, \(+12\%\) yoy.
- GPM recorded \(28\%\) in 1H25, \(+0.6pp\) yoy, implying \(28.9\%\) in 2Q25, \(+1.3pp\) yoy; NPM recorded \(14\%\) in 1H25, \(+1.5pp\) yoy, implying \(14.3\%\) in 2Q25, \(+1.2pp\) yoy.
- Tesla (the biggest customer in the segment) is expected to decline by \(15\%\) yoy in 2025E per management, with its contribution to the segment reduced to \(

GPM and NPM improved significantly mainly driven by economies of scale from strong revenue growth, effective cost control under the company's efficiency initiatives, and a favorable product mix shift toward higher- margin HVAC components and rapidly expanding commercial HVAC demand. Management emphasized that the margin improvement is sustainable, noting that the core driver was internal capability building rather than temporary factors. SG&A as % of revenue decreased to \(11.1\%\) in 2Q25 vs \(12.6\%\) in 1Q25 and \(13.2\%\) in 2Q24. Operating cash flow was healthy with the cash inflow reaching \(Rmb808mn\) , \(67\%\) of net profit in the quarter.
Exhibit 1:Sanhua 2025 financial summary
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Sanhua is a global leader in HVAC control & thermal management components. We are Buy- rated on Sanhua A/H because we like its growth potential in humanoid robot actuators on top of a solid market leadership in core business, and expect to deliver \(19\% /19\%\) revenue/net profit CAGR in 2025- 30E. On the HVAC side, we believe the company is well positioned to deliver revenue growth above the residential HVAC industry, driven by commercial HVAC market share gain and ramp up in sensor products. On the EV side, we believe the company's revenue growth will be driven by further global EV penetration increase and modest content value gain. In addition, we see humanoid robots as a significant long- term technology trend with Sanhua likely to secure a key role in the supply chain, as a high visibility actuator assembler. Catalysts include technology advancement in humanoid robot functionality, volume production for humanoid robot big customers, and further EV penetration in Europe. We view the stock's valuation as undemanding vs. our China Industrial Tech coverage average.
Valuation: Our 12m target price of Sanhua A/H is Rmb32.7/HK\$34.4, still based on 2030E P/E of 21x, discounted back to 2026E with a COE of \(9.5\%\) .

Key upside risks: (1) Easing pricing competition; (2) Headwinds abate towards the company's expansion in new testing areas; (3) Better than expected margins; (4) Faster than expected development from low altitude economy.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
